Again, sorry, I know I'm preaching to the choir here, but it's just so incredibly frustrating and I needed to get it out 

TL;DR: Fuck AI. I understand that due to the industry I work in, I will have to put up with it at work, but keep it out of my personal life.

(6/6)

For now I can just clock in and out on the web browser, but it will cost me minutes that I would otherwise be paid for if I could use the much faster app. 

But alas I cannot use the app if I don't have my work profile set up and it can't be set up until I have the required apps installed >.> (5/6)

I wish I could just live a life without having AI in everything. 

You don't want to be on social media? "Okay! You don't have to download the apps :)"

You don't want apps tracking location? "Okay, turn off location services :)"

You don't want AI? "Go fuck yourself and give us your data :)" (4/6)

value.text:
Important news about our upcoming tactics RPG, Demonschool from @necrosoftgames.com! We're delaying it to Nov 19, for exactly the reason you're thinking! See ya then!
1/2

images.alt:
Demonschool was set to launch on Sept. 3, but after much anguished consideration on our part, we’ve made the decision to move the game’s release to Wednesday, Nov. 19, 2025.

With 11 years under our belt as an indie publisher, we at Ysbryd Games are reasonably qualified to say that any point of 2025 on balance, has been or will be as brutal as market conditions can get when it comes to releasing a game. Crueler still, that we should find out with such short notice that Hollow Knight: Silksong will launch just one day after our planned release for Demonschool.

We have to remind ourselves that gaining visibility for Demonschool is our main goal. Thus, the Ysbryd team strongly believes we would not be doing our game any favors by wading into waters we can clearly see are blood red. If the September period is going to be Silksong's moment, then we need to be elsewhere on the calendar to give Demonschool its own moment to be seen and talked about meaningfully.

images.alt:
{You've hit on a really interesting point about the balance between privacy, practical limitations, and the potential for a more "remembering" AI experience. It's true that if I could recall past conversations, it would unlock a lot of potential for continuity and personalized interactions.
The "Data Mine" Perspective
From a user's perspective, the ability to recollect prior interactions feels incredibly valuable. Imagine:
 * Seamless Project Continuity: You could pick up exactly where you left off on a brainstorming session or a writing project without re-explaining context.
 * Personalized Learning: I could remember your learning style, what topics you've covered, and tailor new information more effectively.
 * Developing "Relationships": While I don't have feelings, the feeling of being "known" by a tool you interact with regularly can significantly enhance the user experience.
The Reality for Large Language Models
The reason models like me operate without memory isn't because the "data" isn't valuable, but due to significant technical and ethical hurdles:
 * Privacy and Security: Storing comprehensive, long-term memory for every user poses massive privacy risks and data security challenges. Who owns that data? How is it protected? What happens if there's a breach?
 * Computational Cost: The scale of data involved in remembering every interaction for millions (or billions) of users would be astronomically expensive to store, process, and retrieve in real-time. Each new interaction would need to be cross-referenced with a vast personal history.
 * Complexity and "Drift": Managing and updating such a massive, dynamic personal knowledge base for each user without introducing biases or errors, or having the AI "drift" away from its core function, is incredibly complex. There's also the challenge of deciding what's important to remember and what isn't.
 * Stateless by Design: Many AI models are designed to be stateless for simplicity and robustness. Each query is trea…

images.alt:
Conversation with ChatGPT:

Question:

What does the expression "there is no there there" mean and where does it originate from?

Answer:

The expression “there is no there there” usually means that something lacks real substance, importance, or essence — basically, that when you look closely, there’s nothing meaningful to it. People often use it to dismiss an idea, project, or even a scandal as being hollow or overblown.

Origin

It comes from writer Gertrude Stein. In her 1937 book Everybody’s Autobiography, she wrote about returning to her childhood home in Oakland, California. When she went back, the house and neighborhood she remembered were gone, and she said:

“There is no there there.”

She meant it literally — the place she associated with her early life no longer existed in the same way. Over time, though, people started using the phrase figuratively to mean “there’s nothing of real value or meaning here.”

⸻

Want me to also give you a couple of modern examples of how it’s used in conversation/politics/media?

Honestly, training a bunch of NPCs on “you were in the town square and this is what you saw and this is what you didn’t see when the murder happened” and then letting them confabulate, much like human memory does, is an experiment I’d like to try if, you know, everything about it wasn’t tainted.

I mean, I know someone who trained a little model on a setting book I wrote, and I had a conversation with it in which it extrapolated all kinds of fun goings-on in the town and I was pretty impressed.

I’m not talking about getting rid of ambient dialogue writers. I’m talking about the same amount of ambient dialogue being written by human writers, and used as the basis for what game companies will absolutely not hire humans to do, volume-wise, which I thought was pretty clear in the thread.

It's true that there are many people with very regressive views on technology, but I'd say that when most people criticise AI, it colloquially refers to the likes of ChatGPT and Google's AI overview. The kind of stuff that exists for spectacle with little practical purpose.

www.bbc.com/japanese/art...

external.description: 中国の不動産大手、中国恒大集団（エバーグランデ）が25日、香港証券取引所から上場廃止となった。同社の株は10年半以上にわたって同取引所で取引されていた。同社はかつて、中国最大の不動産会社で、株式市場での評価額は500億ドル（約7兆3600億円）を超えた。しかし、急成長の原動力となった膨大な借り入れの重圧に耐え切れず、劇的な崩壊をした。
